rules.title: Structure and Use of Citations
rules.text: Provide citations to authorities so that readers may identify and find those authorities for future research. Citations are made in citation sentences and clauses (rule 1.1) and are introduced by signals. Signals organize authorities and show how those authorities support or relate to a proposition given in the text (rule 1.2). Citation sentences and clauses may contain more than one signal. Order signals according to rule 1.3. Within each signal, arrange authorities according to rule 1.4. Parentheticals may be necessary to explain the relevance of a particular authority to the proposition given in the text (rule 1.5). Certain additional information, specific to that authority, may also be appended according to rule 1.6.

children.title: Citation Sentences and Clauses in Law Reviews
Text
children.text: Citations to authorities that support (or contradict) a proposition made in the main text (as opposed to footnote text) are placed in footnotes. A footnote call number should appear at the end of a textual sentence if the cited authority supports (or contradicts) the entire sentence. In contrast, a call number should appear within the sentence next to the portion it supports if the cited authority supports (or contradicts) only that part of the sentence. The call number comes after any punctuation mark—such as a comma, semicolon, or period—with the exception of a dash or a colon. In addition to citation to authorities, a footnote may include textual sentences that are related to the main text to which the footnote is appended.

children.title: Footnotes
children.text: If a footnote itself contains an assertion requiring support, a citation to the relevant authority should appear directly after the assertion as either a citation sentence or a citation clause.

children.title: Citation sentences
children.text: Authorities that support (or contradict) an entire footnote sentence are cited in a separate citation sentence immediately after the sentence they support (or contradict). The citation sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period.

children.title: Citation clauses
children.text: Authorities that support (or contradict) only part of a sentence within a footnote are cited in clauses, set off by commas, that immediately follow the proposition they support (or contradict).

children.title: Example
children.text: The following excerpt illustrates the use of citation sentences and clauses in a law review piece: ► Some American jurisdictions place the burden of sustaining criminal defenses on the accused.1 States have required defendants to prove 1 (Footnote) 1. See John Calvin Jeffries, Jr. & Paul B. Stephan III, Defenses, 112 F.R.D. 259, 264 (1986).
Signals that indicate support include: E.g., Accord, See, See also, Cf. (with explanation). Use these signals when the cited authority clearly supports or directly states the proposition.

Signals suggesting a useful comparison include: Compare... with..., See (other authority). Use these signals when the comparison between the authorities cited will offer support for or analogies to the proposition.

Signals indicating contradiction include: But see, But cf. (with explanation). Use these signals when the cited authority directly states or clearly supports a proposition contrary to the main proposition.
Signals indicating background material include: See generally. Use these signals when the authority provides helpful background information or context for the proposition.
In footnotes, signals may be used as the verbs of textual sentences, but they should not be italicized when used in this way.

children.title: Order of Signals
children.text: When more than one signal is used, the signals (along with the authorities they introduce) should appear in the order in which those signals are listed in rule 1.2. When "e.g.," is used in conjunction with another signal, the other signal's position in rule 1.2 should be used. Signals of the same basic type—supportive, comparative, contradictory, or background (rule 1.2(a)-(d))—must be strung together within a single citation sentence and separated by semicolons. Signals of different types, however, must be grouped in different citation sentences. For example: ► See Mass. Bd. of Ret. v. Murgia, 427 U.S. 307 (1976) (per curiam); cf. Palmer v. Ticcione, 433 F. Supp. 653 (E.D.N.Y. 1977) (upholding a mandatory retirement age for kindergarten teachers). But see, e.g., Gault v. Garrison, 569 F.2d 993 (7th Cir. 1977) (holding that a classification of public school teachers based on age violated equal protection absent a showing of justifiable and rational state purpose). See generally Comment, O'Neil v. Baine: Application of Middle-Level Scrutiny to Old-Age Classifications, 127 U. PA. L. REV. 798 (1979) (advocating a new constitutional approach to old-age classifications). Within a citation clause (rule 1.1), however, citation strings may contain signals of more than one type, separated by semicolons.

children.title: Order of Authorities Within Each Signal
Order of Authorities Within Each Signal
children.text: Authorities within each signal are separated by semicolons. Authorities should be ordered in a logical manner. If one authority or several authorities are considerably more helpful or authoritative than the others, you may choose to list those first, followed by the remaining authorities in a separate sentence introduced by a signal such as "See also." Otherwise, list authorities of the same type (cases, statutes, etc.) in the order of their descending weight or importance.

Certain additional information specific to an authority, such as indication of subsequent case history or explanatory parentheticals, may be provided in parentheses at the end of a citation, according to rule 1.6.

Regardless of the type of authority you cite, it may be helpful to include additional information to explain the relevance of the cited authority. Append such information as a present participial phrase, a quoted sentence, or a short statement that provides context for the citation.

When directly quoting only a short phrase from an authority within a parenthetical, follow rule 1.5(a)(i). For example: ► But see Flanagan v. United States, 465 U.S. 259, 264 (1984) (explaining that the final judgment rule reduces the potential for delay and harassment in the federal appellate process).
When citing multiple authorities in one explanatory parenthetical, separate each authority with a semicolon, and retain their individual explanatory parentheticals if any.
Other phrases may be used by analogy to rule 1.6(a)(i) and (ii), as appropriate (e.g., "microformed on" (see rule 18.5.1) or "translated in" (see rule 20.2.5)).

Explanatory parentheticals should begin with a lowercase letter (unless the first word is a proper noun) and should not start with a quotation mark or a word that would otherwise be capitalized in regular text. The parenthetical is part of the citation sentence and should be treated accordingly with respect to punctuation.

children.title: Related Authority
children.text: Certain additional information, such as information regarding related authority or prior or subsequent history that can properly be indicated with an explanatory phrase (table T8), should not be given parenthetically. Thus, related or subsequent history that is not essential to the disposition of the case, or sources of law that provide additional background context but are not directly pertinent to the proposition, may be omitted or relegated to an "additional information" parenthetical as described in rule 1.5.

rules.title: Typefaces for Law Reviews
rules.text: Legal writing uses four typefaces, though choice of typeface conventions differs between academic writing and practitioner documents. In law review footnotes, specific typefaces (ordinary roman, italics, SMALL CAPS, and LARGE & SMALL CAPS) are used for different parts of a citation to convey meaning and to adhere to traditional styles.

children.title: Typeface Conventions for Citations
children.text: In law review footnotes, case names (including procedural phrases), book titles, and titles of periodicals (including student-written works in periodicals) are in italics. The titles of court documents (such as briefs and petitions) when referred to in text, as well as titles of legislative materials, explanatory phrases, introductory signals, and prior or subsequent history explanatory phrases are in ordinary roman type. Institutional author names in citations and the titles of regulations in a code are in SMALL CAPS.

children.title: Typeface Conventions for Textual Material
children.text: The main text of law review pieces does not contain citations and uses only ordinary roman type and italics. Most material appears in ordinary roman type. Only the following are italicized: (i) case names (including "v." and procedural phrases such as "In re"), (ii) titles of publications, speeches, or articles, and (iii) words italicized for emphasis or style. In footnote text, citations are allowed and can be embedded within textual sentences (rule 1.1(b)). Case names that are part of a textual sentence in a footnote are italicized.

rules.title: Subdivisions
rules.text: Most subdivisions (such as volumes or sections) in published works are identified by abbreviations (table T16). In citations, however, these subdivisions should generally be written out in full (except for well-known acronyms or terms like "section" where the symbol is universally recognized). The specific format for different types of subdivisions is covered in the subrules below.

children.title: Volumes, Parts, and Supplements
children.text: When the work being cited is part of a multi-volume set, or has supplements or pocket parts, indicate the volume number or type of supplement in the citation. For example, if citing a multi-volume treatise, include the volume number followed by the page. If citing a looseleaf service, indicate the service or release number if pertinent.

children.title: Pages, Footnotes, Endnotes, and Graphical Materials
children.text: When citing a specific page, give the page number after the source name. For footnotes or endnotes, use "n." followed by the note number (e.g., "at 15 n.4"). For tables, charts, or other graphical materials without page numbers, use descriptive identifiers (e.g., "Table 2").

children.title: Sections and Paragraphs
children.text: Many legal documents, statutes, and regulations are divided into sections (§) or paragraphs (¶). When citing such subdivisions, use the appropriate symbol followed by the number (without a period). If citing multiple sequential sections, use a double section symbol ("§§"). For nonconsecutive sections, separate by commas.

children.title: Appended Material
children.text: When citing an appendix, preface, foreword, introduction, or other prefatory material, clearly indicate that part. For example, use "at xv (Preface)" or "at 3 (Introduction)". If citing appended statutory or regulatory material, identify it (e.g., "App.").

children.title: Internal Cross-References
children.text: When referring to another part of the same work (such as "supra" or "infra" references in an article), provide a clear reference by part number or heading. Use "supra" or "infra" in italics, followed by a comma and the pinpoint reference, e.g., "Part II.A.1, infra". Do not use "hereinafter" for internal cross-references.

children.title: "Id."
children.text: Use "Id." to refer to the immediately preceding authority when it is the sole authority in the preceding citation and the new citation is in the same footnote or the immediately following footnote. "Id." always refers to the identical source, not just the same general work.

children.title: "Supra" and "Hereinafter"
children.text: Use "supra" to refer to a previously cited authority, typically for secondary sources, legislative materials, or international documents. Provide enough information in the "supra" to avoid confusion (usually the author's last name or a short title). Use "hereinafter" for an authority with a cumbersome name or when multiple works by the same author are cited; it follows the full citation, introduced by a comma, inside the parenthetical (e.g., "("Full Title", hereinafter "Short Title")").

children.title: Formatting of Quotations
children.text: Quotations of fifty or more words should be formatted as block quotations (indented and without quotation marks). Shorter quotations remain in-line with quotation marks. When using a block quotation, maintain the original formatting, including internal quotation marks. Use an ellipsis to indicate omitted material and brackets to indicate changes or additions.

children.title: Alterations and Quotations Within Quotations
children.text: Indicate any alteration to a quoted text with brackets, including added or changed letters or words. Use "[sic]" after an error in the original that is being preserved. When quoting text that itself contains a quotation, alternate between double and single quotation marks (with the outermost quotes determined by the context of your quote).

children.title: Omissions
children.text: Use an ellipsis ("...") to indicate omitted material within a quotation. Do not begin a quote with an ellipsis if the quoted material starts midsentence; simply begin with a lowercase letter (bracketed if needed). Ensure the omission does not alter the fundamental meaning of the quoted text.

children.title: Abbreviations
children.text: Use standard abbreviations for case names (table T6), institutional author names (T7), periodical titles (T10), publishing terms (T8), and geographical terms (T10). Do not abbreviate words in textual sentences (except widely known acronyms), but always abbreviate as shown in tables when in citations.

children.title: Numerals and Symbols
children.text: In text, spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine, and any number that begins a sentence. Use numerals for 100 and above. In citations, use numerals for all numbers (e.g., "115 F.3d 123"). Use symbols (like § and ¶) as appropriate in citations, but in text, use words ("section" or "paragraph") unless referring to a specific section symbol as a symbol.

rules.title: Italicization for Style and in Unique Circumstances
rules.text: Words may be italicized in text for emphasis or stylistic purposes, but use this sparingly. In legal writing, certain terms are traditionally italicized: words used as words, foreign words not commonly used in English, and letters or numerals referenced as such. Additionally, when a word is being defined, it is often italicized. Beyond these, the Bluebook suggests caution in using italics for style.

rules.title: Capitalization
rules.text: Capitalize references to specific constitutional amendments ("First Amendment"), specific acts or laws ("Civil Rights Act"), titles of court documents (when referring to a specific document, e.g., "Plaintiff's Motion"), and titles of periodicals in citations (per Bluebook rules). Do not capitalize generic references ("the amendment" or "the act") or terms like "federal" or "state" unless part of an official name. Additionally, follow specific capitalization rules for judges' titles (rule 9) and court names ("Supreme Court" when referring to SCOTUS, etc.).

rules.title: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court
rules.text: Capitalize the titles of judges and officials when used before a name ("Chief Justice Marshall") or when referring to a specific person ("the President"). Do not capitalize when used generically ("any justice may..."). Terms of court (like "Fall Term") are capitalized when naming a specific term of a specific court. Always capitalize "Court" when naming the U.S. Supreme Court or when the reference is to the court in a case name in text ("the Court held..."). Otherwise, lowercase "court".

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: A full case citation includes the case name (italicized in court documents or underlined/italicized in academic writing), the published reporter volume, reporter abbreviation, first page of the case, pinpoint page if needed, the court abbreviation (if not obvious from reporter), and the year in parentheses. Example: Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 115 (1973).

children.title: General Rules for Case Names
children.text: In case names, omit first names, middle names, and initials of individuals (use just last names). Omit "The" as the first word of a party name. Use acronyms for entities if widely known ("NLRB"), otherwise abbreviate & according to table T6. Always abbreviate certain words (e.g., "Co.", "Inc." per T6) and any word listed in table T6 when it is part of a party name (except when it is the first word of a party name).

children.title: Additional Rules for Case Names in Citations
children.text: Omit all parties other than the first listed on each side of the "v." (unless required for clarity, such as ex rel. parties). Also omit alternative names for the first party (like "AKA" or "d/b/a" entries). Use "In re" or "Ex parte" for certain procedural cases as appropriate. Abbreviate any state, country, or other geographical unit according to T10 when it is part of a case name (except if it's a named party like "State of...").

children.title: Reporters and Other Sources
children.text: For decisions published in reporters, cite to those reporters according to their citation format (e.g., U.S., F.2d, N.E.2d). If a case is unreported, provide an equivalent citation such as a docket number and database identifier, or a court website, or a slip opinion information. For cases in regional reporters, include the region abbreviation. If citing multiple reporters (parallel citations), Bluebook strongly prefers citing only the official or most authoritative reporter in academic writing (some court rules differ).

children.title: Parallel Citations and Which Source(s) to Cite
children.text: When required to provide parallel citations (typically in court documents, not in law reviews), list the citations separated by commas. In law reviews, generally cite only the official or most-used reporter. If citing a public domain citation (for jurisdictions that have adopted such systems), provide that followed by a parallel to a regional reporter if available.

children.title: Reporters
children.text: Abbreviate reporter names as per table T1. Use correct series notation (2d, 3d, etc.). Do not include publisher names in citations (no Lexis or Westlaw in a citation to published reporters). For U.S. Supreme Court, cite U.S. if available; otherwise S. Ct., L. Ed., or U.S.L.W. as required.

children.title: Public Domain Format
children.text: Some jurisdictions assign official citations that do not depend on a reporter (e.g., "1999 ND 45"). When citing cases in these jurisdictions, use the public domain citation followed by a pinpoint (if any) and the court if not evident, plus the year. If also published in a reporter, some rules require including that as a parallel.

children.title: Court and Jurisdiction
children.text: In the parentheses at the end of a citation, include the abbreviation for the court and jurisdiction if not evident from the reporter or context. For state high courts, generally just the state abbreviation and year (e.g., "N.Y. 1990" for New York Court of Appeals). For intermediate state courts or federal courts, include abbreviations ("Cal. Ct. App." or "5th Cir."). Omit the court name if using a state reporter that clearly indicates the court.

children.title: Date or Year
children.text: Always include the year of decision in the parentheses after the court/jurisdiction. If the decision date is essential (e.g., multiple decisions by the same court in one year cited together), include the full date. Otherwise, year alone suffices. For U.S. Supreme Court cases, year alone is used. For recent cases not yet published, you might include the full date.

children.title: Weight of Authority
children.text: If a decision is per curiam, en banc, or a plurality, indicate that in a parenthetical. For example, (per curiam) or (en banc) or (plurality opinion). Only include if it’s not clear from the citation itself or if relevant to the point.

children.title: In-Chambers Opinions
children.text: If citing a single-Justice in-chambers opinion (U.S. Supreme Court), indicate it parenthetically: e.g., "(in chambers)". This distinguishes such rulings (often on stay applications or similar) from the Court’s full opinions.

children.title: Quoting/Citing Parentheticals in Case Citations
children.text: When one case citation is quoted or cited within the parenthetical of another, format the interior citation in normal citation format but do not italicize it (because the parenthetical as a whole is not italicized in law review footnotes, and interior citations remain roman). For example: (quoting Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (1900)).

children.title: Order of Parentheticals
children.text: When multiple parentheticals are needed (e.g., one for weight of authority and one for quoted material), the order is: explanatory parenthetical first, then any subsequent history parenthetical. Keep them as separate parentheticals, not one combined.

children.title: Explanatory Phrases and Weight of Authority
children.text: If a case's prior or subsequent history is significant (aff’d, rev’d, cert. denied, etc.), include it in a parenthetical. Use the abbreviations from table T8 ("aff’d", "rev’d", "cert. denied"). Only include if the history is not already reflected or if it is within two years for cert. denied (Bluebook rule sets a two-year limit on including cert. denials). Place this parenthetical after the main citation but before any explanatory parenthetical that is about the proposition.

children.title: Different Case Name on Appeal
children.text: If the case name changed on appeal (perhaps due to a change in the parties), you may indicate the new name in a parenthetical. For example: (sub nom. New Name v. Original Defendant). Use "sub nom." (under the name of) to introduce the new case name.

children.title: Pending and Unreported Cases
children.text: For cases that are pending (no decision yet) or unreported (no published or official citation), cite to an electronic database (like Westlaw or Lexis) or to the court’s filing information. Include docket numbers and court names and full dates for pending/unreported cases. E.g., Brief for Appellant at 15, Smith v. Jones, No. 20-1234 (U.S. filed Jan. 5, 2020).

children.title: Fifth Circuit Split
children.text: When noting a split of authority in the Fifth Circuit (or any circuit), ensure clarity by citing representative cases from both lines of authority. There is no unique format besides providing citations to the cases that demonstrate the split, possibly with a parenthetical explaining it.

children.title: Briefs, Court Filings, and Transcripts
children.text: For briefs and other court filings, include the document name, page (if pinpoint), the case, and the filing info. Example: Brief for Petitioner at 10, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123). For transcripts, include speaker if relevant and page. Example: Transcript of Oral Argument at 12, Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (No. 18-123).

children.title: Court Administrative Orders
children.text: Cite administrative orders, standing orders, or other court-issued materials by name if available, court, and date. These often are not published; you may refer to the court’s website or another source. The Bluebook does not have a specific unique format beyond treating them similar to other court documents or rules, with the title or order number if any.

children.title: Short Forms for Cases
children.text: After a full citation of a case, you can use a short form in later citations. Acceptable short forms include the case name (if unique) or a shortened case name, with or without a pinpoint cite, or "Id." if the immediately preceding citation is the same case. E.g., "Roe, 410 U.S. at 116." Do not use "supra" or "hereinafter" for cases.

rules.title: Constitutions
rules.text: Cite constitutions by name and section. In text, "U.S. Constitution" can be abbreviated to "U.S. Const." in citations. For state constitutions, use the state abbreviation (e.g., "N.Y. Const."). When citing a specific part, use article, section, amendment abbreviations (e.g., art. I, § 8, amend. XIV). Do not include dates for constitutions in citations. If the constitution is obvious from context, you may drop "U.S." or the state name on subsequent references. Use "Id." for subsequent citations if appropriate.

rules.title: Statutes
rules.text: Cite statutes by their official or popular name (if commonly used) and the published source (code or session law) and year. Federal statutes: cite to the U.S. Code when available: Title U.S.C. § Section (Year). E.g., 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (2018). For state statutes: cite to the current code if available or the session law if not codified. Include the jurisdiction abbreviation if not clear (e.g., "Va. Code Ann."). If citing an unofficial code, indicate the publisher and year parenthetically. Include supplements if applicable ("Supp. 2020").

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: The basic form for statutes: [Official Name of Act], [published source] [section symbol and number] ([year]). If the act is commonly known by a name, you can use that name in italics (for academic writing). Federal code citation: [Title] U.S.C. § [section] ([Year]). State code citation: [State Abbrev.] [Code Abbrev.] § [section] ([Year]). Session law: [Act Name], [Pub. L. or Chapter] No. [number], [volume] [Reporter] [page] ([Year]).

children.title: Choosing the Proper Citation Form
children.text: Use the official code if available (e.g., U.S.C. for federal statutes). If a statute is spread across multiple code sections, cite as a range (e.g., 42 U.S.C. §§ 9601-9675). If the statute is not in the code yet, cite the session law. If an unofficial code is more up-to-date or commonly used in practice, you may use it in court documents (with an indication of currency or year). In law review, typically stick to official codes whenever possible.

children.title: General Rule
children.text: Cite to the current official code (or its supplement) if available; otherwise, cite an unofficial code or the session laws, in that order of preference. Ensure that whichever source is used will allow the reader to find the law easily.

children.title: Exceptions
children.text: In certain circumstances, such as when a statute has been repealed or amended and those changes are relevant, it may be appropriate to cite an earlier version or to a source discussing those changes (like a legislative history or a prior code edition). Another exception is if a jurisdiction requires parallel citation to an unofficial code, in which case follow the local rules.

children.title: Current Official and Unofficial Codes
children.text: Federal: The official code is the United States Code (U.S.C.), published every six years with supplements. Unofficial codes include U.S.C.A. and U.S.C.S. For state codes, most states have an official code; some also have unofficial annotated codes. Always cite the official code if up-to-date; if using an unofficial code for a recent amendment, indicate it. Include the year of the code edition (or supplement) used in parentheses. If citing an unofficial code in a court document, indicate the publisher abbreviation (e.g., West or Lexis) if required by local rules.

children.title: Additional Information
children.text: If the code edition year and the actual text year differ, the Bluebook typically wants the edition year (which is usually on the spine of the volume or the title page). If citing a pocket part or supplement, use the year on that supplement. Some codes also have effective dates or credit information—generally do not include those in citations, but be mindful if a provision’s effectiveness is at issue.

children.title: Year of Code
children.text: When citing the U.S. Code, you no longer need to include a date if the code is current (Bluebook 21st edition changed this rule—federal code citations omit the year if citing the current code). For state codes, include the year of the code volume or supplement if the publisher prints one; if citing an electronic version, use the currency date given.

children.title: Session Laws
children.text: Cite session laws when a statute is not yet in the code or if you want to refer to the law as originally passed. Format: [Official Name of Act], [Pub. L. No. or Chapter] [No.], [Volume] [Reporter Abbrev.] [Page] ([Year]). E.g., Civil Rights Act of 1964, Pub. L. No. 88-352, 78 Stat. 241 (1964). For state session laws, use the state abbreviation and the session law citation format (often year and chapter).

children.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
children.text: When a statute is found only online or in a database (or if that is the source being cited), give a parenthetical indicating the database and currency. For example: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (LEXIS through Pub. L. No. 116-140). If citing a state code online, follow local conventions for currency. Use authenticated PDFs or official websites when possible, and provide a URL if required or if it aids in retrieval (Bluebook rule 18.2.2 might apply as well).

children.title: Other Secondary Sources
children.text: Occasionally you may need to cite a secondary source for statutory material (like a looseleaf, a treatise, or an agency guidance that includes statutory text). Cite those like you would any similar secondary source (rule 15 or 18, etc.), but make clear what part is being cited. It’s usually better to cite the statute directly if possible.

children.title: Invalidation, Repeal, Amendment, and Prior History
Invalidation
children.text: If a statute or part thereof has been held invalid (e.g., unconstitutional), and that information is relevant, include a parenthetical in the citation indicating the disposition. Example: 18 U.S.C. § 3501 (2000) (held unconstitutional by Dickerson v. United States, 530 U.S. 428 (2000)).

children.title: Repeal
children.text: If a statute has been repealed, note the repeal year in the citation if citing an historical version. Example: 42 U.S.C. § 6000 (1988) (repealed 1992). If citing current code, you wouldn't include a repealed section unless you specifically discuss its prior existence, in which case use an explanatory parenthetical.

children.title: Amendment
children.text: If a recent amendment is relevant, you might include the session law of the amendment in a parenthetical or as a separate citation. Generally, if citing the current code, you don't indicate it was amended unless necessary (the code text is presumed current). If discussing a forthcoming amendment, you could cite the public law number that enacted it, as pending or as a reference.

children.title: Prior History
children.text: For acts with complicated histories, you may cite to earlier versions or note former classifications if relevant (e.g., if an act was renumbered or moved in the code). This is rarely needed in standard citation but could appear in historical discussions.

children.title: Explanatory Parenthetical Phrases
children.text: When citing statutes, you might add explanatory parentheticals to clarify how the statute relates to your proposition. E.g., (providing definitions) or (establishing regulatory authority for...). These follow any prior history parentheticals and are similar to case parentheticals in form.

children.title: Internal Revenue Code
children.text: Cite the Internal Revenue Code (Title 26 of U.S.C.) by section alone, but often precede with "I.R.C." for clarity in textual discussions. E.g., I.R.C. § 61. In academic writing, 26 U.S.C. § 61 (2018) is acceptable, but practitioners often just use I.R.C. for brevity when it's understood the reference is to the tax code.

children.title: Ordinances
children.text: Cite municipal ordinances by the name of the municipality and the ordinance (or code) section. E.g., Chicago, Ill., Municipal Code § 8-4-015 (2020). Include the jurisdiction to avoid confusion (city and state). If the ordinance is from a code, specify it's a code. If it's a one-off ordinance not codified, cite the ordinance number and date of passage.

children.title: Rules of Evidence and Procedure
children.text: Cite federal rules as: Fed. R. [Civ./Crim./Evid./App.] P. [Rule number]. E.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 56. State rules similarly: [State Abbrev.] R. Civ. P. [number], or just Rule [number] if context makes clear. For local court rules, include the court name: e.g., S.D.N.Y. R. 4.1. Use "R." for Rule in textual sentences if starting a sentence, otherwise abbreviate in citations.

children.title: Model Codes, Principles, Restatements, Standards, Sentencing Guidelines, and Uniform Acts
children.text: Cite these by name and section if available. E.g., Model Penal Code § 210.3 (Am. Law Inst. 1962). For Restatements: Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 90 (Am. Law Inst. 1981). Uniform Acts: Uniform Commercial Code § 2-201 (AM. LAW INST. & UNIF. LAW COMM’N 2017). Include year of the source. If citing the unofficial version of the UCC as codified, use that citation instead.

children.title: ABA Code of Professional Responsibility and Opinions on Ethics
children.text: Cite the ABA Model Rules of Professional Conduct or Code of Professional Responsibility by rule or DR number, and year if needed. E.g., Model Rules of Pro. Conduct r. 1.7 (Am. Bar Ass'n 2020). For ethics opinions, include the organization, opinion number, and year: ABA Comm. on Ethics & Pro. Resp., Formal Op. 466 (2014).

children.title: Short Forms for Statutes
children.text: After giving one full citation of a statute, you can shorten subsequent citations. Options: Use "Id." if the immediately preceding footnote is the same statute and same section. Otherwise, you can use an abbreviation like the section number and code (e.g., § 1983) if context makes it clear which code is being referenced (with a prior cite to 42 U.S.C. § 1983, you might later just say § 1983, assuming no confusion). Do not use "supra" for statutes; use the short name or abbreviation instead.

rules.title: Legislative Materials
rules.text: Legislative materials include bills, resolutions, hearing transcripts, committee reports, and other documents produced in the legislative process. The citation forms vary: bills and resolutions often by title or number, Congress, and year; hearings by title, committee, Congress, and year; reports by title or number, Congress, session, and year. Always include the relevant legislative body and number (and chamber for reports or documents, e.g., H.R. Rep., S. Rep.).

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: Bills: [Bill number], [Cong. number] Cong. ([year]) (enacted or pending). E.g., S. 1234, 116th Cong. (2019). Resolutions similar: S. Res. 20, 116th Cong. (2019). Reports: [H.R. or S.] Rep. No. [report number], [Cong. number] Cong., [Session if needed] ([Year]). Hearings: Title of Hearing: Hearing Before the [Committee Name], [Cong. number] Cong. ([Year]). Include page if pinpoint citing. Documents: cite as per their nature (reports, hearings, etc.) or use the CIS numbering if necessary.

children.title: Bills and Resolutions
children.text: Include the bill or resolution number, chamber (H.R. or S.), Congress number, and year of introduction or enactment. If citing a specific version, you can add a parenthetical like (as introduced) or (enacted). Example: H.R. 2500, 117th Cong. § 3 (2021). If the bill name is well-known or adds clarity, you can include it before the number in italics (for law review style): [Name of Act], H.R. 2500, 117th Cong. (2021).

children.title: Hearings
children.text: Include the title of the hearing (in italics in academic writing), the committee name (and subcommittee if applicable), the number of Congress, session if needed, and year. e.g., Data Privacy: Hearing Before the S. Comm. on Commerce, Sci. & Transp., 116th Cong. (2019). If the hearing has a serial number or publication number, that might be optionally included (some choose to include the publication info after the parenthetical). Always include the year.

children.title: Reports, Documents, and Committee Prints
children.text: Committee reports: H.R. Rep. No. 115-10 (2017) or S. Rep. No. 115-10 (2017). House and Senate documents or committee prints similar format: identify as H.R. Doc. or S. Doc. or Comm. Print, then number and Congress, session, year. If a report has a title, you may include it in italics before the report number (for law review style). Always indicate which Congress and whether it's 1st or 2d Session if the numbering restarts each session (for many reports, including year suffices).

children.title: Debates
children.text: Cite Congressional debates to the Congressional Record (Cong. Rec.). Format: [Volume] Cong. Rec. [page] (year). If pinpoint citing, you can parenthetically indicate the speaker and brief context if helpful (though Bluebook style often doesn’t require naming the speaker if clear from context). Example: 165 Cong. Rec. H1234 (daily ed. May 5, 2019) (statement of Rep. Smith). Use daily edition if the permanent bound edition is not available or if pinpoint requires daily ed. page.

children.title: Separately Bound Legislative Histories
children.text: If a compiled legislative history exists (often assembled by committees or librarians), cite it as a book, if it has book-like citation info. For example: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996: Legislative History, Pub. L. No. 104-191, compiled by [Name] (1997). Include page numbers if citing specific parts. However, most legislative history citation is to individual documents rather than a compiled volume.

children.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
children.text: When legislative materials are accessed via databases like ProQuest Congressional or Congress.gov, provide basic citation as per print, and add a parenthetical indicating the database and any identification number if relevant, or a URL if appropriate. Example: H.R. Rep. No. 115-10 (2017), 2017 WL 123456 (Cong. Rep.). Use the WL or LEXIS citation if no print is easily accessible, with the database identifier. For hearings or debates available online, you might give a URL parenthetically if it aids in retrieval.

children.title: Short Forms for Legislative Materials
children.text: Subsequent citations: You can use "Id." if referring to the same item as immediately preceding. Otherwise, use a shortened form of the report or hearing title, or just the report number, etc., as appropriate. E.g., S. Rep. No. 115-10, at 5. Or, "2017 Hearing, supra note 12" if you introduced the hearing with a hereinafter. Bluebook encourages avoiding supra for cases and statutes, but for legislative materials, using supra and hereinafter can be acceptable to avoid lengthy repetitive citations.

rules.title: Administrative and Executive Materials
rules.text: Administrative materials include rules and regulations (often cited to the Code of Federal Regulations or state equivalents), administrative adjudications, agency decisions, and executive orders and proclamations. Cite rules to the CFR when codified; if not yet codified, to the Federal Register. Cite administrative adjudications similar to cases (with an indication of the agency or board). Executive orders and proclamations are cited by number and publication source.

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: Regulations: [Volume] C.F.R. § [section] ([Year]). Use the current edition year of the CFR. If citing a proposed or not-yet-codified rule: [Volume] Fed. Reg. [page] ([Date]). Agency decisions: similar to cases, give the case name (if any), reporter (like a decisions reporter or looseleaf), and date. If an agency decision is not in a reporter, cite the agency's release or decision number and date. Executive orders: Exec. Order No. [number], [volume] Fed. Reg. [page] ([year]). Presidential proclamations similar form.

children.title: Rules, Regulations, and Other Publications
children.text: For rules and regulations: cite to the CFR if available. If multiple sections, you can use "et seq." or list multiple sections. If citing material from the Federal Register, provide the full date. If citing agency manuals, guidance, or press releases, treat them as institutional author documents (with the agency as author) and provide titles and dates. For example: U.S. Food & Drug Admin., Guidance for Industry: ... (Year).

children.title: Names
children.text: If an administrative adjudication has a style or name, use it (e.g., In re [Party], or [Party] v. [Agency]). If not, you might cite the docket or decision number as title. Use the name as given in the reporter or the agency's decision document.

children.title: Which Source(s) to Cite
children.text: If decisions are reported (e.g., in an official decisions reporter of the agency), cite that. If not, cite to a commercial reporter or a slip opinion, or an electronic source. Many agencies have their own reporters (like NLRB decisions in NLRB volumes, etc.). Use those if available; otherwise, use a service like Pensions or Labor decisions reporters or Lexis/Westlaw cites.

children.title: Issuing Agency
children.text: It can be helpful to indicate the agency in the parenthetical if not evident. For example, (FTC 1984) after a citation to a Federal Trade Commission decision. If the reporter already indicates the agency, no need. For arbitration decisions, name the arbitration panel or body if needed in the citation or parenthetical.

children.title: Commercial Electronic Databases
children.text: If using an electronic database citation for an administrative decision or rule (because it’s not easily available in print), give an appropriate parenthetical with the database and information. E.g., (FAA Order No. 2018-1, Westlaw). If using a slip opinion from an agency website, consider giving the URL or enough info to find it. The Bluebook generally wants you to cite to print or official sources if available, so resort to electronic citations if necessary and with proper parentheticals.

children.title: Short Forms for Regulations
children.text: Use "Id." if the immediately preceding citation is to the exact same regulation. Otherwise, you can shorten a regulation citation by using just the CFR section number if the context (and prior full cite) make it clear which title and year. E.g., if 40 C.F.R. § 261.4 was fully cited earlier, you could later cite "§ 261.4" within a discussion of EPA regs, but clarity is key. Alternatively, use "supra note" if referring back to a footnote where full citation was given (though for regulations, repeating the citation or using id. is more common).

rules.title: Books, Reports, and Other Nonperiodic Materials
rules.text: This rule covers how to cite books, treatises, reports, white papers, encyclopedias, dictionaries, etc. The basic format: Author, Title (edition year). Include authors as name in full as given on the publication (for up to two authors, list both; for more than two, use first author et al. in academic citations). Titles are italicized. Include edition if not first, publisher if helpful (Bluebook usually requires publisher for lesser-known works or when citing a specific edition of a code or multi-volume work). Always include the year of publication.

children.title: Author
children.text: Include the author's full name as it appears on the title page. For multiple authors: for two authors, list both (John Smith & Jane Doe); for more than two, list the first author followed by "et al." in academic writing. In practitioner documents, some local rules prefer listing all authors up to a certain number. If an institutional author (like a government agency or organization), use that name exactly as given, abbreviating according to Bluebook rules (e.g., U.S. Environmental Protection Agency would be "EPA" per Bluebook if using acronym, but typically spelled out unless a well-known acronym).

children.title: Editor or Translator
children.text: If citing a work by an editor or translator (with no named author) or if you want to note an editor/translator, put that name after the title, preceded by the abbreviation "ed." or "trans.". For example: William Blackstone, Commentaries on the Laws of England * ___ (John Doe ed., 2020). Use plural "eds." if multiple editors. If author is present, editors typically not included unless the edition is primarily associated with the editor (like a specific edited volume).

children.title: Title
children.text: Italicize book titles. Capitalize each word in the title except articles, conjunctions, and prepositions (unless they begin the title or subtitle). If the work is part of a series or multi-volume set and you are citing the series, you might include that information after (e.g., volume number). For subtitles, include them after a colon. E.g., "Title: Subtitle". If citing a specific essay or chapter within a book, see rule 15.5.

children.title: Edition, Publisher, and Date
children.text: If not the first edition, include the edition number (in superscript if possible, e.g., "2d ed."). Always include the year of publication. The publisher is generally not required in law review citations except for less common works or when needed for clarity (the Bluebook often omits publisher for books published by a main legal publisher, focusing on edition and year). However, for reports by organizations, the organization can be listed as the author or as the publisher depending on how it’s cited. When in doubt, provide enough info to identify the source clearly.

children.title: Works in Collection Generally
children.text: When citing an essay, article, or chapter within an edited collection, cite the author of the piece, title of the piece (in quotes, not italics), then "in" the book title (italicized), then the page on which the piece begins, the editor, edition (if applicable), and year. Example: John Doe, Essay Title, in Book Title 123, 130 (Jane Smith ed., 2d ed. 2020). 123 is where the piece starts and 130 is the pinpoint. If multiple editors, use "eds.". If a multi-volume work, include volume number before book title if citing specifically from one volume.

children.title: Collected Documents
children.text: If citing a document reprinted in a collection (like a letter in a compilation of letters, or a historical document in a documentary collection), you may cite: Document Description, in Book Title [page] (Editor Name ed., Year). E.g., Letter from X to Y (Dec. 1, 1900), in 5 Collected Letters of X 67 (Z Editor ed., 2000). Provide sufficient details in the document description (date, addressee, etc.) to identify it.

children.title: Prefaces, Forewords, Introductions, and Epilogues
children.text: Treat these similarly to works in a collection: cite the author (which might be different from the main text's author), identify it as "Foreword" or "Introduction" etc., then "in" the book title. If the main work has an author and that author is different, you can indicate that too. For example: Jane Doe, Introduction, in John Smith, Book Title at xiii (2020). Here xiii is the page of the introduction. If the introduction has a title, include it like a chapter title in quotes.

children.title: Serial Number
children.text: If a report or book is part of a series (like a report series or publication series) and is numbered, you can include the series name and number after the title or in the parenthetical. For example: U.N. Doc. A/54/PV.23 (1999) – here "A/54/PV.23" is effectively a serial number for a UN document. For other series (e.g., a university working paper series), you might cite as: Author, Title, Univ. of X Working Paper No. 123 (2020).

children.title: Special Citation Forms
children.text: Some publications have special citation forms (like looseleaf services or court rules pamphlets). Follow the citation guide for those specific forms (which may be covered in other rules or tables). Generally, provide author (if any), title, and as much information as needed (like release or update info). Looseleafs often want a date of the last update. E.g., 2 Charles Alan Wright et al., Federal Practice & Procedure § 1234 (3d ed. 2019).

children.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
children.text: If a book or report is accessed online, cite to the print format if possible. If not, cite as an electronic source: include author, title, (year), and then a parenthetical with "available at" and the URL. For databases (like an e-book in Westlaw), you might indicate the database if relevant. But Bluebook tends to treat books by their print citation even if you read it online, unless it's something like an eBook-only publication.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: Subsequent citations of books can use a short form: typically the author's last name and a pinpoint (and possibly a short title if multiple works by that author are cited). e.g., Doe, supra note 5, at 100. Or if using id.: Id. at 100 (if the immediately preceding note is the same source). Use hereinafter if the title is long and you want to shorten it in subsequent cites: provide a hereinafter in the first full citation. E.g., ... ("Short Title"). Then use Short Title, supra.

children.title: Short Forms for Works in Collection
children.text: If you cited a chapter or essay in a collection, short form can use the chapter author’s last name and "supra note X". If multiple chapters from the same book are cited, you may need hereinafter for the chapter title or the book title to clarify. The key is to avoid confusion between sources. E.g., Doe, supra note 12, at 45 (short form for a chapter by Doe in a multi-author book).

rules.title: Periodical Materials
rules.text: This covers law review articles, journal articles, magazine and newspaper articles, and other serial publications. Basic format: Author, Title, Volume Periodical Name Page (Year). Periodical names are abbreviated per table T13 (for law journals) or T10 (for general terms). Use small caps for periodical names in law review footnotes. Include an issue number or month only if needed (for non-consecutively paginated journals or magazines).

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: Academic journals: [Author], [Title], [Volume] [Journal Abbreviation] [First page] ([Year]). Magazines: [Author], [Title], [Magazine Name], [Month Day, Year], at [page]. Newspapers: [Author], [Title], [Newspaper Name], [Date], [if pinpoint, at page]. Law review example: John Doe, Article Title, 123 Harv. L. Rev. 456 (2020). Magazine example: Jane Smith, Article, Time, Jan. 1, 2020, at 20.

children.title: Author
children.text: List authors as they appear. For multiple authors of an article: for two, list both; for more than two, use first author followed by "et al." (in law review writing). For unsigned notes or comments, if an institutional author is given, use it; if not (like an unsigned student note), you might begin with the title. Bluebook often allows indicating "Comment" or "Note" as part of the title if no author.

children.title: Title
children.text: Article titles go in italics in academic writing (or regular type within quotes in court documents). Capitalize words according to normal rules (not in all caps). If citing a specific type of student work (note, comment), some journals include that in the title or you can add parenthetically. Ensure the title is exactly as published (including any punctuation like a question mark).

children.title: Consecutively Paginated Journals
children.text: Most law reviews and many journals are consecutively paginated throughout a volume, so you only need volume and page. Volume 10 starts on page 1 and goes to 1000, etc. Therefore, just provide volume number, journal name, first page of article. No issue number or month is needed as the volume/year combo is sufficient.

children.title: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines
children.text: If each issue of a periodical starts at page 1 (like a monthly magazine), include the issue date or number. For example: 23 Nat’l L.J., no. 5, at 12 (2020). Or, The Economist, Mar. 3, 2021, at 54. Provide the exact date for newspapers and magazines. For academic journals that are numbered by issue, include the issue number if pagination is not continuous: e.g., 4(3) Int'l J. of Law 15 (2020) – meaning volume 4, issue 3, page 15.

children.title: Newspapers
children.text: Cite newspapers by author, title, newspaper name (italicized in law reviews), date, and pinpoint page. If no author, start with title. If an edition (like "late edition") matters, you can note it parenthetically if needed. Example: John Doe, Article, N.Y. Times, Jan. 5, 2021, at A1. If citing an online newspaper article, cite to the print if also in print; if online-only, include the URL and indicate (online) if required by context (see rule 18).

children.title: Student-Written Law Review Materials
children.text: Indicate the type if desired: for example, for a student note or comment, some law reviews italicize "Note" or "Comment" before the title. Bluebook doesn't strictly require denoting it's a student piece, but if the piece is unsigned and the journal identifies it as a "Note" or "Comment," you can treat that word as part of the title. If the student author’s name is known, cite normally with the name.

children.title: Non-Student-Written Book Reviews
children.text: For a book review article, you can parenthetically indicate the book being reviewed if not clear from title. Some journals put book info as part of title or in a footnote. Bluebook rule: Cite the review as an article, but you may add, e.g., (reviewing [Book Info]). Example: Jane Doe, Title of Review, 130 Harv. L. Rev. 123 (2017) (reviewing John Smith, Book Title (2016)).

children.title: Symposia, Colloquia, and Surveys
children.text: If citing an article that is part of a symposium or special issue, you can optionally indicate that by a parenthetical if relevant (e.g., (Symposium: Law and Technology)). Usually, this is not required unless needed for clarity or context. If the symposium issue has its own title on the cover, it’s usually not included in each article citation.

children.title: Commentaries and Other Special Designations
children.text: Some journals have sections like "Notes," "Comments," "Essays," "Developments," etc. If the journal itself includes those in the titles or differentiates them (like Harvard Law Review's "Recent Cases" or "Developments" issues), treat the piece as an article with whatever title is given. If needed for clarity, you could include a parenthetical like (commentary) if it’s an informal piece, but Bluebook generally cites by what's given.

children.title: Multipart Articles
children.text: If an article is published in multiple parts across issues, cite each part separately by its specific citation. Do not combine unless you are referencing the work as a whole, in which case you might cite all parts separately in one footnote or just the first part with a footnote explaining it spans multiple issues.

children.title: Annotations
children.text: Law journal annotations (like an Annotation in A.L.R.) are treated like articles but often have the form: [Author], Annotation, [Topic], [volume] A.L.R. [series] [page] ([Year]). Follow the format given by that series. For example, John Doe, Annotation, Validity of..., 12 A.L.R.5th 123 (1993).

children.title: Proceedings, Regular Publications by Institutes, and ABA Section Reports
children.text: If an institute or ABA section publishes regular volumes or reports (like an annual proceedings or survey), cite those similar to books or reports. E.g., Proceedings of the ABA Section of Antitrust Law 2018, at 45 (2019). Or if it's an institute's continuing legal education material, provide the title of the article/panel and information about the publication (which might be akin to an edited volume citation).

children.title: Newsletters and Other Noncommercially Distributed Periodicals
children.text: Cite newsletters by the organization as author if no individual author given, title of the newsletter (if any), and date. If they are not widely available, include information like (on file with author) if appropriate. For example: ACLU Privacy Newsletter, Jan. 2020, at 2. These often fall under rule 17 (unpublished) if not widely accessible. Use judgement to provide enough info for retrieval.

children.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
children.text: If an article is only available online or you accessed it online, Bluebook suggests citing it as per print as much as possible. If only online, include a URL and maybe a parenthetical ("available at"). For example, Jane Doe, Blog Post Title, LAW BLOG (Jan. 2, 2020, 10:00 AM), https://lawblog.com/post. If citing an online journal ahead of print, you may cite the DOI or an "forthcoming" designation if applicable. In general, see rule 18 for internet sources, but periodical rule defers to that for online periodicals.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: After a full citation, you can short cite periodicals by last name and a supra reference or id. as appropriate. E.g., Doe, supra note 4, at 460. Or just Id. if the immediately prior citation is the same article and same page series (with possibly different pinpoint). If multiple works by same author, include a short title as well to distinguish. Bluebook does not allow "supra" for cases and certain primary sources, but for articles it's fine.

rules.title: Unpublished and Forthcoming Sources
rules.text: Unpublished materials include manuscripts, working papers, dissertations, letters, memos, etc., that are not formally published. Forthcoming sources are those accepted for publication but not yet out. Cite unpublished material by describing it (and if applicable, where on file), and forthcoming by indicating the expected publication.

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: Unpublished: Author, Title (unpublished [descriptor] [year]) (on file with ...). Example: John Doe, Article Draft (unpublished manuscript, 2020) (on file with author). Forthcoming: cite like published but replace year with "forthcoming" and include the journal or publisher if known. Example: Jane Smith, Book Title (forthcoming 2021). If in a journal: ... 123 Harv. L. Rev. (forthcoming 2022).

children.title: Manuscripts
children.text: For manuscripts that are not formally published, provide as much information as possible: Author, Title (date) (unpublished manuscript) and where it is (on file with ... or available at ... if online). If part of a collection, note the collection. Use descriptive parentheticals to clarify the nature (e.g., "draft").

children.title: Dissertations and Theses
children.text: Cite dissertations like: Author, Title (unpublished Ph.D. dissertation, University, year). For LL.M. theses or J.S.D. dissertations, similarly specify. If it's published in Dissertation Abstracts or a database, you could cite that source. But generally treat as an unpublished manuscript with university info.

children.title: Letters, Memoranda, and Press Releases
children.text: These may be cited as: [Author name], [Description] ([Date]) (on file with ...). For example, Letter from John Doe to Jane Smith (Jan. 5, 2020) (on file with the Columbia Law Review). For memoranda or internal documents, similar format, naming the document if it has a title or a brief description. If citing a press release that's not easily found, treat it like a short document: Organization, Press Release, Title (Date) (on file with ...).

children.title: E-mail Correspondence and Listserv Postings
children.text: Cite email like a letter: Email from [Author] to [Recipient] (Date, Time) (on file with ...). If a listserv or forum posting, you can do: [Poster Name], Message, [Name of Listserv] (Date, Time) (on file with ... or URL if archived). Often, if the content is accessible online, one might prefer to cite the online source with rule 18 format.

children.title: Interviews
children.text: For unpublished interviews, cite: Interview with [Name, Title], in [Location] (Date). If you're the interviewer, you could mention that (with author). If a recording or transcript exists, cite that if possible. Example: Interview with John Doe, former Dir., ABC Agency, in New York, N.Y. (May 5, 2020). If the interview is by telephone, you could say (telephone interview).

children.title: Speeches and Addresses
children.text: Cite speeches: [Speaker], [Title of Speech] (Date). If unpublished, maybe (transcript on file with ...). If published in a source, cite that source. If you just have details of the event, include event info: e.g., Speech, Location, Date. Example: Remarks of Jane Doe at the Annual Meeting of the XYZ Ass'n (May 1, 2020).

children.title: Forthcoming Publications
children.text: Cite forthcoming journal articles as: Author, Title, [Volume if known] Journal Name (forthcoming Year). For books: ... (forthcoming Publisher Year). If the year is known or likely, use it; if not, you might omit or say (forthcoming). If an article is accepted but volume/issue not assigned, just (forthcoming). If just submitted, treat as a manuscript rather than forthcoming.

children.title: Working Papers
children.text: Many working papers (like SSRN drafts) can be cited similar to unpublished manuscripts: Author, Title (Working Paper, Organization Year). If a specific working paper series: Author, Title, ABC Institute Working Paper No. 123 (2020). If available online, you might add a URL parenthetical. The Bluebook generally says to treat them as unpublished unless they have a specific series reference.

children.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
children.text: If an unpublished or forthcoming source is available online (like a draft on SSRN or an online repository), include the URL and date accessed if required (see rule 18). For example: John Doe, Draft Title (Apr. 2020) (unpublished manuscript), https://ssrn.com/abstract=123456 (last visited Jan. 1, 2021). For forthcoming, you might not have a URL yet, just cite as forthcoming.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: Short cite unpublished sources by last name and a supra note if possible (assuming you gave a full citation in a prior footnote). E.g., Doe, supra note 10. If only one work by Doe is cited, that suffices. If a letter or interview, you might refer to it in text or use an id. if it’s clear. Bluebook doesn’t have special short forms beyond using supra for previously cited miscellaneous sources.

rules.title: The Internet, Electronic Media, and Other Nonprint Resources
rules.text: This rule addresses how to cite websites, blogs, social media, video/audio recordings, and other non-print materials (like films, broadcasts, etc.). Key principles: provide the author (if any), the title or description of the item, the date (if any), and the URL. For media, provide format info (like DVD, video, audio). For online sources, include "last visited" dates if required by context (Bluebook requires last visited date if no publication date is evident or if content is likely to change).

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: For Internet sources: Author (if identifiable), Title of the page or document, Name of the Website (if different from title), URL, and a parenthetical with the date (either last visited or publication date if available). Example: U.S. Census Bureau, Population Estimates, http://www.census.gov/data.html (last visited Jan. 1, 2025). If an article on a news site: use the format for periodical but include URL and (last visited date) if no print analog.

children.title: General Internet Citation Principles
children.text: Try to find author, title, and date for web content. If the title is not obvious, use the heading of the page or a descriptive title in brackets. Use "last visited" for dynamic content. For stable or archived content with a clear date, the date can suffice. Always include the full URL (if extremely long, Bluebook now allows using a shortened URL in some cases as long as it is accessible).

children.title: Citations to Internet Sources
children.text: Include the protocol (http:// or https://). If a URL is extremely long, you can use a URL shortener in brackets (Bluebook suggests avoiding if possible). If citing something like a PDF or a specific page on a website, cite to that page's URL. If content might move (like a blog entry that might scroll), consider citing a permalink or archived version via perma.cc if available. Indicate "last visited" date if no other date is present on the site.

children.title: Commercial Electronic Databases
children.text: Cite cases, statutes, etc., from Westlaw/Lexis with their conventional citation (no need to mention database unless it's unpublished or unique to that database). For materials unique to databases (like a looseleaf or a treatise on Lexis), cite as you would the treatise in print if possible, or add a database identifier. For example, if citing a case available only in Westlaw: Name, No. 12345, 2020 WL 123456 (Year). Bluebook de-emphasizes naming the database in citation if a neutral citation can be given.

children.title: CD-ROM and Other Electronic Storage Media
children.text: If citing material from a CD-ROM, DVD, or similar, treat it like the print but indicate the medium if relevant. Example: The Federalist No. 10 (James Madison) (CD-ROM, 1996). For most legal citations, CD-ROM content is rare now, but older Bluebook allowed adding format info. The key is clarity: provide author/title and then parenthetical (CD-ROM).

children.title: Microform
children.text: Microform (like microfiche or microfilm) citations are treated similar to print but you might indicate the format if relevant. If citing an archive accessible only via microfilm, you might cite the document and then parenthetically say (available on microfiche at [location]). Typically, however, one would cite the original publication and not worry about the fact that one accessed it on microform.

children.title: Microform Collections Reproducing Preexisting Materials
children.text: If the microform is a reproduction of a known source (e.g., NY Times on microfilm), cite as if to the original, possibly adding a parenthetical that it's on microfilm collection. If referencing a microform collection specifically by name, you might cite the collection: e.g., FBI File No. __, in FBI Records Collection, microfilm at reel X (Nat’l Archives). Use by analogy to rule 17 for unpublished.

children.title: Microform Collections Containing Original Materials
children.text: If the microform collection itself is the primary publication of the material (like an unpublished set of papers published on microfiche), cite it like an unpublished material with a parenthetical indicating the microform: e.g., John Doe Papers, microfiche, at frame 123 (Univ. X Archives). Provide enough detail (collection name, collection editor if any, year).

children.title: Films, Broadcasts, and Noncommercial Video Materials
children.text: Cite films by title (italicized), director, production company, and year. Example: The Social Network (Columbia Pictures 2010). For TV or radio broadcasts: Title of Segment, Network (Date). If citing an episode of a series: "Episode Title," Series Name (Network airdate Month Day, Year). For online videos (like YouTube), provide the creator or poster, Title, platform, and date posted, URL.

children.title: Commercial Recordings
children.text: Cite music recordings by Artist, "Song Title," on Album (Record Label Year). Or for classical: Composer, Title (Performer or Orchestra, Record Label Year). If citing liner notes or such, treat as part of that medium. The idea is similar to citing a book: give enough info to identify the track and album.

children.title: Noncommercial Recordings
children.text: If citing a noncommercial recording (like a privately recorded interview, etc.), treat it like an unpublished source: e.g., Interview with X (audio recording on file with author). Or Oral Argument at 5:32, Doe v. Smith, No. 123 (XYZ Court Jan. 1, 2020) (audio recording). Provide an identifier (like time stamp if relevant).

children.title: Podcasts and Recordings Available Online
children.text: Cite podcasts similar to other online media: Host, Episode Title, Podcast Name (Date), URL (if needed). E.g., John Doe, Episode 5: Title of Episode, Law Talk (Jan. 1, 2020). Include the platform if relevant or just use the URL. For transcripts, if you have one, you could cite as you would a written interview with appropriate credits.

children.title: Photographs and Illustrations
children.text: Cite photographs or images by describing them and giving source info. For example: John Smith, Photograph of [Subject] (2019), available at https://... . If in a book or database, cite that: Photograph, in Title of Book (Publisher Year) or Photo credit if given. Illustrations in books are usually cited via the book citation with a pinpoint to the figure or page.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: Short cite internet and media sources using "supra" with the author's name or a short title, as with other secondary sources. For example: Doe, supra note 15 (if note 15 was a web page). For cases or statutes found online, use normal short forms. If the source has an idiosyncratic title, you might use a hereinafter to simplify. For example, if a URL is the citation, in a footnote you might create a hereinafter like ("DOE BLOG"). Subsequent citations can then use DOE BLOG, supra. As always, ensure it's clear what you're referring to.

rules.title: Services
rules.text: Services refer to looseleaf and electronic services that provide compilations of primary law and analysis (like tax services, CCH looseleafs, etc.). These can be cited like books or periodicals depending on how they are organized. Often, they have paragraph or section numbers rather than pages.

children.title: Citation Form for Services
children.text: Cite the service by name, publisher (if helpful), and pinpoint. Many services have preferred abbreviations. For example: 5 CCH Cons. Fin. Guide ¶ 72,205 (2019). Here, volume 5 of the Commerce Clearing House Consumer Finance Guide, paragraph 72,205. If the service is electronic, indicate the database (e.g., Westlaw) if needed. If the service is organized by release, you might cite release or issue.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: Short cite services by name (if unique) and paragraph/section. E.g., CCH Cons. Fin. Guide, supra note 10, ¶ 72,205. Or simply Id. if immediately previous. Services often have continuous updates, so ensure the supra still points to the same material (services can update paragraph numbers, but assume static).

rules.title: Foreign Materials
rules.text: This covers citation of foreign legal materials. The Bluebook has extensive tables (T2) for specific countries. General rules: use the official source of foreign law if available, in the original language, with an English parenthetical explanation if needed. Provide jurisdiction if not obvious.

children.title: Jurisdiction
children.text: Always indicate the country (and subdivision like state or province if needed) unless it’s obvious from context. Use table T2 for abbreviations. For example, cite an English statute: [Name of Act] [year] (UK). Or a French code: C. civ. art. 1234 (Fr.). If writing in English and the source is not in English, consider adding an English title in parenthesis if known.

children.title: Non-English-Language Documents
children.text: If citing a source in a language that uses the Roman alphabet, cite in the original language, but you may provide an English translation of the title in parenthesis. If language uses a non-Roman alphabet (Chinese, Arabic, etc.), transliterate the title (Bluebook provides guidance in T2 or elsewhere) and then parenthesize the English translation. Include language or jurisdiction in parenthesis if needed for clarity.

children.title: Documents Appearing in More than One Language
children.text: If a document is officially published in multiple languages (like some Swiss laws in German, French, Italian), cite the version you are using and can read. If an English version is official or authoritative, you can cite that. If not, cite the original, and perhaps note the existence of translations if relevant. For example, cite a Quebec law in French even if an English version exists unofficially, unless an official English is provided.

children.title: Titles and Names of Documents in Languages Other than English
children.text: Capitalize foreign titles according to the capitalization rules of that language. Italicize case names or titles of books as in English. For example, in French, only the first word and proper nouns are capitalized in titles. Provide an English translation of the title in parenthesis if the reader might not understand the original. For example: Loi relative aux sociétés par actions [Law on Joint Stock Companies] (Belgium).

children.title: Abbreviations in Languages Other than English
children.text: Use the foreign-language abbreviations as per local convention or table T2. Do not translate abbreviations of source names. For instance, "OJ" for Official Journal of the EU, or "BVerfGE" for a German case reporter, should remain as is. If necessary, provide a parenthetical explanation for a less-known abbreviation on first use.

children.title: Languages That Do Not Use the Roman Alphabet
children.text: Transliterate non-Roman scripts. Use the system given in Bluebook table (for example, pinyin for Chinese, Hepburn for Japanese, etc.). Once transliterated, treat as a foreign title (with italicization rules as appropriate). Provide English in parenthesis. For example, Supreme Court of Japan [Saikō Saibansho], or a case name transliterated and then (Japan).

children.title: Citations to Translations of Non-English-Language Documents
children.text: If you are citing a translation, indicate the translator and that it’s a translation. E.g.,  Civil Code of Germany, translated in 2 The German Civil Code: As Amended to January 1987, at 123 (Simon L. Goren trans., Fred B. Rothman & Co. 1994). Also, if you quote a translated passage, you might parenthetically credit the translation.

children.title: Cases
children.text: Cite foreign cases with the case name (if applicable, italicize as in English), the volume/reporter/page (if analogous to common law citation), and the court and date in parenthesis. Many civil law countries use case numbers and dates instead of reporter citations, so adapt accordingly: e.g., Bundesverfassungsgericht [BVerfG] [Federal Constitutional Court] Mar. 3, 2004, 111 Entscheidungen des Bundesverfassungsgerichts [BVerfGE] 307 (Ger.). Use the format provided in table T2 for each country.

children.title: Common Law Cases
children.text: Cite as: [Case Name] [year/volume] [Reporter] [page or case number] ([Court abbreviation] [Year]). For example, R. v. Smith, [2001] 2 S.C.R. 42 (Can.). If country uses year in brackets, follow their style. Always include jurisdiction if not obvious from reporter (e.g., include country or province as needed).

children.title: Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Cases
children.text: Often no official case name; you might use the parties or a descriptor. Provide docket or decision number if available, court name, date. Example (Germany): BVerfG Mar. 3, 2004, 111 BVerfGE 307 (case regarding ...). For France: Conseil d’État [CE] [Council of State] June 27, 2014, Rec. Lebon 312. Use available references like official gazettes or court bulletins as specified in T2.

children.title: Constitutions
children.text: Cite foreign constitutions by country name and then constitution (in English if known) and pinpoint. Example: Constitution of the Italian Republic art. 5. Or in original language if required: Grundgesetz [GG] [Basic Law] art. 1 (Ger.). Provide year of adoption or amendment if relevant and not clear by context (some cite as (Germany 1949) if multiple constitutions in history).

children.title: Statutes
children.text: Cite foreign statutes by official name (possibly translated in brackets if needed), the promulgation or code information, and date. Civil law countries often: Law Name (date) (Country). For codes: give the article number and code name. Example: Code civil [C. civ.] art. 1382 (Fr.). For session laws: cite to official gazette if applicable (e.g., Official Journal citation). Use T2 for specifics.

children.title: Statutes in Common Law Systems
children.text: Common law jurisdictions often mirror U.S./U.K. style: Title (Jurisdiction year). e.g., Australian Consumer Law, Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) sch 2 (Austl.). Use their official compilation or session law citation as appropriate. Include jurisdiction abbreviation if sub-national (like Ontario or New South Wales).

children.title: Statutes in Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Jurisdictions
children.text: Civil law: often use the date and title: e.g., Gesetz über die ... [Act on ...], Oct. 1, 2020, BGBL I at 123 (Ger.). Or the year/number style: e.g., Law No. 100 of 2006 (Japan). Table T2 gives each country’s preferred format, including whether to include the publication reference like an official gazette citation. Provide an English description in brackets if title is not self-explanatory.

children.title: Non-English-Language and Foreign Periodicals
children.text: Cite foreign journals similar to U.S. journals, but use the original title abbreviation (per T13 for that language) and include an English translation of the title in parenthesis if not obvious. e.g., 20 Revue Internationale de Droit Comparé 25 (1988) (Fr.) ("International Review of Comparative Law"). If the article title is foreign, you can translate it in a parenthetical if helpful.

children.title: Short Citation Forms
children.text: Use id., supra, etc., for foreign sources similarly. If you've given an English hereinafter, use that. E.g., German Civil Code, supra note 10, § 823. Or id. if appropriate. Ensure not to confuse foreign sources with domestic ones if similar names; clarity may require including the country in the short cite if needed (e.g., "BGHZ, supra note 12" if used as abbreviation for German case reporter).

rules.title: International Materials
rules.text: This covers treaties, international cases, U.N. documents, EU materials, and other international law sources. Generally, cite treaties by official U.S. sources if available (U.S.T. or I.A. etc.), or U.N.T.S for multilateral treaties. Cite international cases from the court reporters (like I.C.J. Rep.), and U.N. documents by U.N. document numbers.

children.title: Basic Citation Forms
children.text: Treaties: [Agreement Name], [date], [volume] [Reporter] [page]. E.g., Charter of the United Nations art. 2, June 26, 1945, 59 Stat. 1031, 3 Bevans 1153. International cases: [Case Name] ([Year]) [Reporter] [page]. UN documents: U.N. Doc. [symbol] ([Year]). EU regulations/directives: cite Official Journal (e.g., 2016 O.J. (L 119) 1).

children.title: Non-English-Language Documents
children.text: For treaties or international agreements in a language other than English, if there is an official English translation, cite that if you are writing in English. Otherwise cite the original language title italicized, followed by an English translation in brackets. Use the same approach as foreign domestic laws for language handling. Example: [Russian title] [English title] art. X, Feb. 1, 1995, [citation].
